lines.text: It'll be three years before I finish medical school. Even then there won't be any diamond sunbursts or marble halls.
I don't want diamond sunbursts, or marble halls. I just want you.
[Anne is deeply depressed, and Marilla tries to cheer her up by offering her some homemade plum puffs]
Plum puffs won't minister to a mind diseased in a world that's crumbled into pieces.
Well I'm glad to see that your dented spirits haven't injured your tongue.
You set your heart too much on frivolous things and then crash down into despair when you don't get them.
I know. I can't help flying up on the wings of anticipation. It's as glorious as soaring through a sunset... almost pays for the thud.
Well, maybe it does. But I'd rather walk calmly along and do without flying AND thud.
I went looking for my dreams outside of myself and discovered, it's not what the world holds for you, it's what you bring to it.

"Wilt thou give up thy garter, oh fairest of the fair"? Anne, nobody speaks that way. And look at that sap Percival who sits around mooning the entire time. He never lets a girl get a word in edgewise. In real life she'd have pitched him.
Our friendship, it won't ever be the same now. Why can't he just be sensible instead of acting like a sentimental schoolboy?
Because he loves you.
He loves me? I can't know why.
Because you made Josie Pye and Ruby Gillis and all of those wishy-washy young ladies who waltzed by him look like spineless nothings.
Marilla, he's hardly my idea of a romantic suitor.

Anne, you have tricked something out of that imagination of yours that you call romance. Have you forgotten how he gave up the Avonlea school for you so that you could stay here with me? He picked you up everyday in his carriage so that you could study your courses together. Don't toss it away for some ridiculous ideal that doesn't exist. Hmm? Now, you come downstairs and see if a good cup of tea and some of those plum puffs I made today don't hearten you.

[about Rachel Lynde's husband Thomas]
It's a wonder he got sick at all without asking her permission.
You just think that you love me.
Anne, I've loved you as long as I can remember. I need you.
I feel as though someone's handed me the moon... and I don't exactly know what to do with it.
What are you thinking?
I'm afraid to speak or move for fear that all this wonderful beauty will just vanish... like a broken silence.
[Rachel and Marilla discuss Anne]
It's to your credit you changed her as much as you did.
Ooo, she hasn't changed that much... not really. It's US that's changed, Rachel.
[Anne has just invited Miss Brooke to Green Gables for the summer]
Now you can go through the motions of telling me how delighted you are and how I'll have a wonderful time.
I AM delighted... but as to a wonderful time... that will depend entirely on YOU, Katherine.
Anne, There's not going to be any wedding anymore.
You're gonna get well, Gil. I know you are.
I called it off. It wouldn't be fair to Christine. There would never be anyone for me but you.
I promise I'll always be here if you need me. Good friend are always together in spirit. Let's not change Gil, let's just go on being good friends.
Friends, huh? I thought we were kindred spirits.
[whispers forlornly]
Please say yes.
I can't. Gil, I'm so desperately sorry.
[runs off while a heartbroken Gil looks after her]
Fortunately for you, Josie, the only thing you've ever had to wear twice is a sour expression.
This is the first place I've ever been to that feels like a real home.
There's a book of revelations in everyone's life.
This has taught me a lesson not to stake my word of honor on cows.
All pioneers are considered to be afflicted with moonstruck madness.
Why do people have to grow up and marry, change?
Oh, you'd change. If someone ever admitted that they were head over heels for you, you'd be swept off your feet in a moment.
I would not, and I defy anyone who would try and make me change.
Oh, you do?
I don't want any of it to change. I wish I could just hold on to those days forever. I have a feeling things will never be the same again, will they?
I won't change, that's the least I can promise you.
Maybe you don't think I'm good enough for you now, but I will be someday.
No, Gil you're a great deal too good for me. But you want someone who'll adore you. Someone who'll be happy just to hang on your arm and build a home for you. I wouldn't.
Anne, that's not what I'm looking for at all.
We'll end up like two old crows fighting all the time. I know I'd be unhappy and I'd wish we'd never done it.
Don't get up on your high horse with me, Anne Shirley!

[before the start of her wedding]
Oh, I'm so nervous. I know I'm going to faint, Aunt Jo.
Well, if you do, I'll drag you down to the rainwater hog shed and drop you in.

[Anne is taking Mrs. Harris out for a picnic]
I don't eat my lunch outside! I'm not a raggle taggle gypsy! Take me in! Take me in!
Hush, Mrs. Harris! Some of these girls are Pringles.
Pringles?
Yes, and you don't want them running home and telling tales.
You'll pay for this.

[Gilbert has insulted Anne's writing]
Listen, I'm sorry. What else can I do?

[she hits him with her basket of flowers]
Let me get a word in edgewise once in a while, before I pitch you!
Anne Shirley, I wouldn't trade you for a dozen boys.
You won't win that Blythe boy back by punishing him.
I wonder why everyone seems to think I ought to be with Gilbert Blythe.
Good morning, Mrs. Harris.
Walking as if we owned the world, are we?
So I do.
If Gil were to... not knowing how I really care.
Oh, there, there.
What would I do without him?
We can't change what God wills.

[Anne never told Marilla about the book she published]
Oh, you're a great one for secrets.
Myra Gillis had 37 doilies when she got married, and I'm determined to have AT LEAST as many as she had.

I suppose it would be impossible to keep house with only 36 doilies. But I assure you, Mr. Wright, Diana will be the sweetest little homemaker in the world... so long as you can afford to let her keep up with the Gillises.
Maybe if you just let your character speak everyday English, instead of all that highfaluting mumbo jumbo.
Oh. Remember your manners. And don't forget to cross your ankles decently when you sit down. And don't sit in a draft, either. And don't slide down the banisters.
Mama!
Well, you did at Nancy Pringle's wedding.
Mama, that was 25 years ago! What do you think I am ?
Babies are never common. Each one is a miracle.
Well I had two of them. I didn't see much that was miraculous about either of THEM.
I've always held that early marriage is a sure indication of second-rate goods that had to be sold in a hurry.
Mama hates Isaac as much as she did 15 years ago when she set the bull terrier on him for coming around to see me.
Every baby is the sweetest and the best.
Tell me, Mr. Allen, do you dance as well as you boast?
Better.
I am sorry, but the fence that separates your potato field from our pasture is an eyesore. And if you'd kept it in better repair, Dolly wouldn't have broken in.

A jail fence wouldn't keep that devil out. And what's more, my Thomas has been far too ill the past six months to repair any fences. And I know one thing, you red-headed snippet! You'd be better employed fixing that fence yourself rather than mooning around, wasting your time, writing for some rubbishy magazine.

I would rather spend my time profitably than squander it in idle gossip, meddling in other people's affairs. I won't cherish any hard feelings against you because of your narrow-minded opinions. But, thank goodness I have an imagination which allows me to understand how it must be to find a cow amongst prize-winning cabbages. Dolly shall never break into your field again. I give you my word of honor on that point.

[to Anne]
Authors are such kittle kattle. I wouldn't trust your description of any of us.
Hate has got to be a disease with me.
Patience has ceased to be a virtue, I want this rumpus stopped right now!
Fred is... extremely good.
That is exactly what he should be! Would you want to marry a wicked man?
Well, I wouldn't marry anyone who was really wicked, but I think I'd like it if he could be wicked and wouldn't.
You'll have better sense some day, I hope.

[holding the package Marilla has just handed her]
My book! It's the book I published.
Well, don't sit there shaking like a leaf open it.

[to the cow]
Don't even think about Rachel's cabbages.
Well, the elegant and illustrious Miss Shirley. Relaxed while seeking out ideas for her next Rollings Reliable writing assignment, I presume.

[Gilbert has hit her with his riding crop]
I am not your horse, Mr. Blythe!

[making fun of the woman who will be singing at Diana's wedding]
Can you just see the buttons popping off her corset!
What is to be the pill in all this jam, Miss Shirley?

Yes, he was the handsomest man in Kingsport. And he adored me. We consulted each other about absolutely everything. Mind you, we didn't always agree. No. He had his fits of temper. Oh, yes. And so did I.
[laughs]
Do you know what he did when I bought a daycap he didn't like?
I can't imagine.
He ate it. It gave him a terrible stomach pain. Yes, serves him right. He was so irked that I had neglected to consult him.
[laughs/cries]

How could he go away and leave me alone and crippled like this? Dying was the only thing that he ever dared to do without consulting me. Won't be long before we're together again. There's no one - no man like him. No. This is a degenerate age, Miss Shirley.

[about Anne not being married at her age]
It's the overparticular ones that get left behind.
And it's the over-opinionated ones that end up unhappy and meaner than second skimmings.

[meeting Mrs. Harris for the 1st time]
How do you do, Mrs. Harris?
Far from well.

[to Emmeline]
It's high time someone reminded her what a piano sounds like.
[plays a wrong chord]
It shouldn't be me.

[to Pauline]
And if I'm not here when you come back just lay me out in my wedding dress and mind my hair is crimped.
What's the meaning of this outrage? I've had enough of your monkey shine!

[to Katherine Brooke]
You say you like people to be frank, we'll I'm going to be frank. It's your own fault that nobody likes you. Katherine Brooke, you are nothing but prickles and stings!
Would you do me the honor, Miss Shirley, of reserving a waltz on your card?
Of course, Mr. Harris... if I have a waltz free.

[calling Emmaline Harris "telescope eyes"]
Oh, "telescope eyes" wouldn't know a Pringle if she were face to face with one.

[breaking up a fight]
Have you girls no propriety? This is not a Turkish bazaar!
My husband never ate anyone, dead or alive.
Did you know Gilbert Blythe was dying?

[to Gilbert]
Good grief, you sure know how to try one's patience.

[to Gilbert about her book being published]
It hasn't happened yet, you fool, and don't you dare tell anyone!

[about Diana becoming engaged]
Of all the stupid, sentimental thinks for Diana to do.

[to Gilbert]
Last one to the bridge is a stuffed goose!
You always have to be the center of attention whenever Gilbert Blythe is in anyone's company!
Oh, that Anne Shirley is so smug!

[seeing the banner congratulating her on her story]
Great Jehosophat!

[crying on her bed]
Oh, Marilla, such a Jonah day.

[to Mrs. Barry]
Tears aren't lucky at weddings.
